summary: more than 60% of the newly diagnosed HIV cases in the united states in 2009 were MSM [1] in the WHO European Region, the proportion of MSM among new HIV infections was estimated to be 20% in 2010 [2]. the epidemic has also increased among MSM populations in africa and Asia; the UNAIDS report in 2010 showed that the HIV prevalence among MSM aged 15–49 years varied from 12% to 44% in seven countries in sub-Saharan Africa. china has invested substantial funds and human resources into public health programs for HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment, such as needle exchange and methadone maintenance programs for injection drug users [13], [14] and free combination antiretroviral therapy programs for rural and/or poor urban residents living with HIV/AIDS [15], [16]. by 2011, China had successfully obtained the Global Fund round 3, 4, 5, 6, and 8 projects (China GF-3, 4, 5, 6 & 8) china GF-5 project sought to prevent a new wave of HIV in 6 low-prevalence provinces (Heilongjiang, Jilin, Liaoning, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Gansu) and one municipality in China (Chongqing) study data collected in 4 rounds of annual cross-sectional epidemiological surveys. men aged 18 years or older with self-reported anal or oral sexual behavior with a male partner in the past 12 months were eligible. most participants recruited using a snowball sampling method. amusi 407 297 302 300 1,306 there was no difference of condom use between post-intervention and baseline surveys. ivariable and multivariable logistic regression analyses were performed pooling all participants in the four surveys. predictors included in the models were study year, age, marriage, education, ethnicity, residence, occupation, recruitment venue, age at first sex with a man, and 6-month drug use. the target populations included the four HIV aforementioned populations: MSM, CSWs, IDUs and migrants. interventions were implemented during 2006 and 2009. about 5,000 MSM were recruited in each survey (n = 20,843 for all four rounds) participants completed questionnaire interview on demographics, HIV knowledge and attitudes, history of STIs, history of HIV testing, and prior experience of receiving HIV/STI counseling and intervention services. a rapid test (HIV (1+2) Antibody (Colloidal Gold) was used in the 2006 and 2007 surveys. positive specimens were confirmed for HIV infection using Western blot. the participants with syphilis infection were referred to local STI clinics. men aged 18 years or older with self-reported anal or oral sexual behavior with a male partner in the past 12 months were eligible. most participants in these surveys were recruited using a snowball sampling method [19]. 0 52 Yinchuan 55 0 312 200 567 Chongqing 952 740 602* 600* 2,894 Total 5,076 4,981 5,460 5,326 20,843 Participants were recruited using respondent driven sampling. post-intervention survey in 2009 and baseline survey in 2006; and hypothesis 2: there was no difference of HIV prevalence between post-intervention and baseline surveys. analysis methods The distributions of categorical variables across 4 rounds of surveys were compared using Pearson's chi-square test. hypothesis 1: there was no difference of condom use at last sex with a male sexual partner between post-intervention survey in 2009 and baseline survey in 2006. hypothesis 2: there was no difference of condom use between post-intervention and baseline surveys. study year, age, marriage, education, ethnicity, residence, occupation, recruitment venue, age at first sex with a man, and 6-month drug use were included. a composite intervention score was created with one point for receiving each intervention in the past 12 months, therefore the score had a value ranging from 0 to 6. a quarter (26%) of men were married in the 2006 survey, this was only 18% in the 2009 survey. about one third of participants had received college education, and 15%–17% in each survey were currently enrolled in colleges. local male sexual partner increased over time, from 58% in 2006 to 81% in 2009. the difference of condom use rates between those who received and who did not receive interventions was 13%–17% over 4 project years. the coverage rate among the study participants may not represent the overall coverage rate of the interventions for MSM in the cities targeted. a 13% to 17% difference of condom use rates between those who did not receive interventions and those who did not receive interventions. the strategy should focus on both preventing new infections and treatment as prevention as prevention. study participants recruited from multiple cities, improving generalizability. study limitations include lack of HIV incidence data and lack of a comparison group. participants who received interventions may have been affected by interventions due to intervention diffusion. public health programs are vital to reaching people who have not received intervention services.
